metadata.case_name: Messrs. Hind State Private Ltd. & Ors. v. Respondent

facts.text: On May 19, 1953, Messrs. Hind State Private Ltd., predecessors-in-title of the appellants, filed suit for eviction against the respondent on ground of non-payment of rent.

On November 24, 1958, Second Munsif, Alipore, passed decree for possession in favour of plaintiffs holding respondent not entitled to protection under West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950 due to defaults in rent payment.
Decree confirmed in appeal by Subordinate Judge, 4th Court, Alipore, on April 12, 1967.
During pendency of appeal, appellants purchased right, title and interest of plaintiffs and obtained assignment of decretal rights, brought on record in place of original plaintiffs.

Respondent filed Second Appeal No. 1255 of 1967, dismissed by Division Bench of Calcutta High Court on January 8, 1969 after contested hearing; granted time to vacate till end of January 1970 on written undertaking to hand over possession.
West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950 repealed by Section 40 of West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act, 1956.
During emergency proclaimed February 20, 1968, West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act, 1956 amended by Presidents Act 4 of 1968 with retrospective effect from August 26, 1967.
Post-emergency, West Bengal Premises Tenancy Amendment Act, 1969 re-enacted Presidents Act 4 of 1968 with modifications.
West Bengal Premises Tenancy Second Amendment Act, 1969 came into force on November 14, 1969, introducing Section 17D.
On January 12, 1970, respondent applied under Section 17D to set aside decree for possession.
On July 15, 1970, Munsif, Second Court, Alipore, dismissed application holding trial court decree merged in High Court decree of 1969, post-August 26, 1967, so Section 17D inapplicable.
Respondent filed revision in Calcutta High Court against Munsif's judgment.
On May 31, 1971, single Judge of Calcutta High Court allowed revision, granted Section 17D application, directed dismissal of suit, holding no merger when appellate court dismisses appeal.
Supreme Court granted special leave to appellants to appeal from High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the decree of the trial court has merged in the decree of the High Court.
Whether by reason of Section 17D of the West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act, 1956, the decree for eviction is incapable of execution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Decree of trial court dated November 24, 1958 merged in decree of High Court dated January 8, 1969, which was passed after August 26, 1967, so Section 17D inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Doctrine of merger; Jowad Hussain v. Gendan Singh

respondent_arguments.text: Principle of merger has no application where appellate court merely dismisses the appeal; effective decree is that of trial court dated November 24, 1958, before August 26, 1967, entitling respondent to benefit of Section 17D.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of U.P. v. Mohammad Nooh; State of Madras v. Madurai Mills

court_reasoning.text: Doctrine of merger applies: judgment of inferior court ceases to exist and is superseded by judgment of superior court after contested hearing; no distinction between dismissal, modification or reversal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: There cannot be more than one operative order governing the same subject-matter.

court_reasoning.text: Section 17D empowers setting aside operative decree capable of execution; in cases of appeal after contested hearing confirming trial decree, executable decree is that of appellate court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court decree of January 8, 1969 supersedes trial court decree.

court_reasoning.text: Cited precedents affirm merger even on mere affirmance; distinguished cases like Mohammad Nooh as special facts not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entire decree challenged in appeal; subject-matter identical.

holdings.text: Trial court decree dated November 24, 1958 merged in High Court decree dated January 8, 1969.
High Court decree passed after August 26, 1967; Section 17D inapplicable; decree capable of execution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jowad Hussain v. Gendan Singh Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree of appellate court is final and executable; limitation runs from appellate decree.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v. M/s. Amritlal Bhogilal & Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Appellate decision is operative even if merely confirms; original merges therein.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collector of Customs, Calcutta v. East India Commercial Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Merger applies even where appellate authority merely dismisses appeal without modification.

precedents_cited.case_name: Madan Gopal Rungta v. Secretary to the Government of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Order on review petition causes merger in higher authority's order.

precedents_cited.case_name: U.J.S. Chopra v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Merger applies to judgments in appellate jurisdiction after full hearing.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shanker Ramchandra Abhyankar v. Krishnaji Dattatryaya Bapat
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle of merger applies to revisional jurisdiction as part of appellate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Somnath Sahu v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Merger in appellate order even if merely affirms.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammad Nooh
precedents_cited.relevance: Special facts; merger limited for certain purposes like limitation, not general execution.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Madurai Mills Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No merger if subject-matter not identical in revision.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Premises Tenancy Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to set aside decrees passed before commencement of 1968 Amendment on default in rent payment, if possession not recovered; applies to executable decree.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Premises Rent Control Temporary Provisions Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for original eviction decree due to default in rent.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Premises Tenancy Amendment Act, 1968 (Presidents Act 4 of 1968)
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrospective from August 26, 1967; cut-off date for Section 17D decrees.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Premises Tenancy Second Amendment Act, 1969
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced Section 17D effective November 14, 1969; 60 days to apply.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Revisional and appellate jurisdiction; merger principles.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment dated May 31, 1971, and restored Munsif's judgment dated July 15, 1970 dismissing Section 17D application.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for eviction restored and executable.

key_quotes.text: The juristic justification of the doctrine of merger may be sought in the principle that there cannot be, at one and the same time, more than one operative order governing the same subject-matter.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines core principle of merger doctrine.

key_quotes.text: In cases where the decree of the trial court is carried in appeal and the appellate court disposes of the appeal after a contested hearing, the decree to be executed is the decree of the appellate court and not of the trial court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Directly applies to facts; resolves merger issue.

key_quotes.text: The decree which section 17D empowers the court to set aside is the decree which is capable of execution which, in this case, is the decree passed by the High Court on January 8, 1969.
key_quotes.speaker: court
